title: Problem Overview
content: Erdős Problem #686: Can every integer N ≥ 2 be written as ∏(m+i)/∏(n+i) for some k ≥ 2 and m ≥ n+k? From [Er79d]. Products of consecutive integers relate to factorials and binomials. OPEN.
mathContext: The ratio equals C(m+k,k)/C(n+k,k). Finding the right (n,m,k) triple for each N requires subtle divisibility.

title: Consecutive Products
content: consecutiveProduct(n,k) = ∏_{i=1}^k (n+i). consecutiveProduct_eq_factorial (axiom): equals (n+k)!/n!. product_binomial_relation (axiom): equals k! * C(n+k,k). Three examples verified by native_decide.
mathContext: The fundamental building block. Products of consecutive integers have rich divisibility properties.

title: Ratio Expression
content: ratioExpression(n,m,k): P(m,k)/P(n,k) as a rational number. IsIntegerRatio: P(n,k) | P(m,k).
mathContext: Taken over Q for exact division. Equals C(m+k,k)/C(n+k,k) since k! cancels.

title: Main Conjecture (OPEN)
content: IsRepresentable(N,n,m,k): k ≥ 2, m ≥ n+k, ratio = N. Representable(N): ∃ such triple. ErdosConjecture686: ∀ N ≥ 2, Representable(N). Problem remains OPEN.
mathContext: k ≥ 2 excludes trivial single-factor ratios. m ≥ n+k ensures non-overlapping ranges and ratio > 1.

title: Structural Properties and Examples
content: numerator_gt_denominator (axiom): m ≥ n+k implies P(m,k) > P(n,k). ratio_gt_one (axiom): ratio > 1 under the constraints. Example: ratioExpression 0 2 2 = 6 (native_decide).
mathContext: Each factor in the numerator exceeds the corresponding denominator factor. N = 6 is the simplest verified case.

title: Follow-Up: Fixed Parameter Sets
content: RepresentableSet(n,k): {N | ∃ m ≥ n+k, ratio = N}. ratio_mono (axiom): ratio increases with m. representable_set_infinite (axiom): the set is infinite for k ≥ 2.
mathContext: For fixed n,k, as m increases the ratio grows without bound. Which integers appear in this set?

title: Summary: OPEN
content: erdos_686_statement (proved): ErdosConjecture686 ↔ ∀ N ≥ 2, ∃ n m k, k ≥ 2 ∧ m ≥ n+k ∧ ratio = N. Proved by simp. erdos_686_status (proved): True. Problem remains OPEN.
mathContext: The simp proof unfolds the definitions to show equivalence. Problem is open since [Er79d].
